Griz felt each strike as a flicker of satisfaction in the back of his mind, a fleeting taste of stolen warmth from the Weaver’s perspective. The hunger was a living entity inside his head, a roaring furnace that threatened to burn his own consciousness to ash. It showed him the pathetic, flickering life-force of the guards, tiny flames he could snuff out with a thought. It whispered to him of the sweet, final peace of absolute emptiness, the release from the grubby, painful struggle of existence. He fought back with the only weapons he had: the memory of a plastic stegosaurus, the rough texture of a discarded brick, the infuriatingly cheerful way Pip chewed her lip when she was concentrating. He clung to the small, stupid, concrete details of his life, a litany of worthless treasures against a tide of cosmic nihilism.

“Pip!” he screamed, his voice a raw tear in the fabric of the cavern. “The hum… it’s changing! It’s trying to hide! A higher pitch… like a mosquito whine!” He felt the knot’s frequency shifting, trying to evade the pure tone of Pip’s machine. In his mind’s eye, the monstrous hunger recoiled from the clean note, twisting and contorting to find a silence where it could not be heard. One of the tendrils, faster than the others, slithered over the top of the shield wall, its tip aimed directly at Gorn. The farmer, paralyzed by terror, could only stare as it descended. With a roar, Krunk lunged, shoving Gorn aside and taking the full impact of the tendril on his own heavy shoulder pauldron. The metal plate didn't dent, but it turned instantly black, and Krunk bellowed in pain and shock, stumbling to one knee as a wave of numbing cold shot down his arm.

“Almost there!” Pip yelled, her knuckles white on a smaller tuning dial. Sparks flew from an overloaded capacitor on her machine, and the air filled with the acrid smell of burnt insulation. “It’s fighting me, Griz, the resonance is unstable! I need you to hold it! Pin it down!” He understood her meaning immediately. He couldn’t just be a passive observer, a living compass needle. He had to engage. He had to force the knot to hold its frequency, to face the music. He stopped clinging to his memories and did the one thing that went against every instinct. He pushed his own consciousness toward the hunger. He met the void not with defiance, but with a sliver of his own stubborn, goblin will. *You want my life?* he thought, a silent scream into the mental abyss. *You want my memories? Come and get them. Come and get the shame of my name, the ache in my bones, the taste of river water. Take it all.*

It was the psychic equivalent of offering a hand to a starving beast. The Weaver’s hunger, surprised by this offering, latched onto him. The pain was absolute. It was the feeling of being unwritten, of his past being consumed and digested in real-time. But for one precious second, the knot’s frantic frequency shifting stopped. It held steady, focusing all its energy on this unexpected feast. “Now!” Griz shrieked, a sound of pure, unadulterated agony that made every goblin in the cavern flinch. Pip slammed her hand down on a large, red button on her device. The whining of her machine ceased, replaced by a single, impossibly pure, bell-like tone. It was a note of such profound and perfect clarity that it seemed to vibrate not in the air, but in the very essence of the stone and the soul.

The effect was instantaneous and catastrophic. The knot on the Great Root did not explode. It shattered. With a crystalline ringing that echoed the pure tone of Pip's machine, the solid black mass cracked, brilliant white light pouring from the fissures. The shadow tendrils, just moments from overwhelming Krunk's battered guard, froze in mid-air and then dissolved into harmless wisps of smoke. The entire knot crumbled, breaking apart not into pieces, but into fine, black dust that was caught and carried away on a sudden, clean breeze that seemed to spring from nowhere. The ground gave one final, violent shudder, and then, all was silent. The bell tone faded, leaving behind an emptiness that was not the sterile void of the Weaver, but the peaceful, waiting silence of a garden after a storm.

Griz felt the connection sever with the jarring finality of a snapped cable. The all-consuming hunger vanished, leaving behind a hollowed-out ache in his soul. He was himself again, but a lesser version, a thing that had been scraped clean from the inside. He pitched forward, the world going gray at the edges, his strength utterly spent. His last conscious act was to look down at the snow globe still clutched in his hands. The roiling black mist within was gone. In its place, at the bottom of the glass, lay a single, dark, solid fleck, like a shard of obsidian no bigger than a grain of sand. A scar. He saw the soft, blue-white light of the fungal stalks around him flicker, then brighten, their healthy glow pushing back against the encroaching gloom. Then the light, the cavern, and the worried face of Pip swimming above him all dissolved into a welcome and absolute blackness.Griz did not so much wake as drift upward through layers of profound silence. For the first time in what felt like a lifetime, the incessant, buzzing hum was gone from the back of his mind. The absence of the Weaver’s hunger was a void so complete, so stark, that it was almost as disorienting as its presence had been. He was left with only his own familiar symphony of pain: the deep, grinding ache of his ribs, the raw scrape of his heels, and the dull throb of a dozen lesser bruises. It was a purely physical misery, and in the blessed silence of his own head, it felt almost like a comfort. He was alone in his own body again. He opened his eyes to the familiar sight of the spiraling blue fungi on the ceiling of his borrowed cavern, the light steady and clean.

Pip was asleep in a chair fashioned from a rusted-out engine block and a pile of rags, her head resting on a workbench littered with the guts of her Resonance Breaker. The machine was a mess of scorched wires and a single, cracked quartz crystal, a hero that had died in the moment of its victory. Her face, even in sleep, was etched with exhaustion, but the tight lines of frantic worry were gone, replaced by a deep, settled weariness. He had the sudden, fierce urge to let her sleep for a week, to build a wall around her and stand guard against a world that had demanded too much of his only friend. He owed her a debt he could never repay, and the thought was a heavy, unfamiliar stone in his gut.

He sat up slowly, testing the limits of his battered frame. The room was warmer than before, the air clean and smelling faintly of roasting fungus and savory spices. A new bowl of broth sat on the stone beside him, still steaming. He was a patient, an invalid, and the role chafed at his ingrained self-sufficiency. As he reached for the bowl, he saw the snow globe. It was back on its mossy pillow in the wall recess. From this distance, it looked almost normal, the water clear again. He knew better. He knew about the tiny black shard that now rested at its bottom, a permanent scar on his tiny, perfect world. He felt its presence not as an active thrum, but as a cold, dense spot in the room, like a chip of absolute winter that no amount of warmth could touch.

His quiet assessment was interrupted by the heavy felt curtain being pushed aside. Krunk entered, followed by Elder Fizzwick. The Guard Captain’s arm was in a sling, and the metal of his pauldron was still a dull, lifeless black, but he stood tall, his usual gruff demeanor replaced by something Griz had never seen on the old warrior's face: quiet respect. Fizzwick, ever the diplomat, offered a small, weary smile. "The Wound-Bearer awakes," the elder said, his voice soft. "The whole of the Warren gives you thanks, Grizelda. The rot has ceased its spread. The fields are already beginning to recover their light."

Griz flinched at the name and the title. "Don't call me that," he grumbled, his voice thick with disuse. "And Griz is fine."

"A hero earns his name, and his titles," Krunk stated, the words a simple declaration of fact. "You stood against the shadow. You bled for the Warren. You are the Wound-Bearer. It is who you are now." The finality in the captain's voice was absolute. Griz looked down at his bandaged hands. He had spent his entire life defined by his shame, his uselessness, his solitude. Now, in the space of a single day, he had been redefined by others. He wasn't sure which was worse. He felt like a piece of interesting scrap that had been claimed and repurposed without his consent.

"We have formed a council," Fizzwick continued, pulling up a small stool. "Myself, Krunk, Gorn of the farms, and Pip, representing the Tinkers. The old ways are not enough. The threat you faced is not a cave-in or a flash flood. It is a war, and we have been caught unprepared."

"The war's over for now," Griz said, gesturing vaguely at the cavern around them. "We won."

"We won a skirmish," Krunk corrected him, his good hand resting on the pommel of a heavy iron cleaver at his belt. "We cut off one of the enemy's hands. But the head is still out there. And it's angry. It knows we can fight back now. It will not make the same mistake twice." The old soldier's logic was brutal and inescapable. The Weaver was not some mindless blight; it was an intelligence, and Griz had just given it a very painful, very public lesson.

"So what do you want from me?" Griz asked, the question heavy with a resignation that tasted like ash. "You want me to go back up there? Fight it again?"

"We want you to be our eyes," Fizzwick said gently. "That... thing," he nodded toward the snow globe, "it showed you the knot in the deeps. It is our only advantage. We are blind, Griz. You are the only one who can see in the dark."

The pressure was building again, a slow, inexorable tide of responsibility. He was a scout, a seer, a sentinel. They were hanging the fate of their entire world on a goblin who, a week ago, considered finding a complete set of plastic cutlery a major victory. He wanted to scream at them to leave, to take their titles and their councils and their war and let him crawl back into his hole. Instead, he just looked at the snow globe, at the clear water and the tiny, solitary fleck of black. He had to know. He had to understand the new shape of his curse. With a deep sigh, he pushed himself off the bed and limped toward the recess. Krunk and Fizzwick took an involuntary step back as he reached for it, as if he were handling unexploded ordnance.

The glass was cold to the touch, the familiar vibration gone. It felt inert, dead. He held it in his palms, turning it over, watching the single black shard slide across the bottom of the glass. It was nothing more than a broken toy again. A wave of bitter relief washed over him. Maybe it was over. Maybe the magic had been spent, burned out in the final, purifying tone. He let his thumb brush against the glass directly over the shard.

The world did not dissolve. It fractured. A single, razor-sharp image, colder and clearer than any vision he had experienced before, pierced his mind like an ice pick. He saw a vast, empty street, slick with rain under the orange glare of Topside streetlights. He saw the Weaver, its bruised, elongated form standing over the crumpled, metal-and-plastic corpse of the tangle-hound Griz had buried under the pallets. The Weaver was not raging. It was unnervingly still. It reached down, its long, shadowy fingers brushing the wreckage, and Griz felt a flare of cold, analytical fury that was not his own. It was a fury mixed with a grudging respect, the anger of a master craftsman whose work has been unexpectedly dismantled by a clever apprentice. And then, the Weaver's head lifted, and its shadow-filled eyes seemed to look directly at him, through him, across the miles and the layers of rock and concrete. He was not just seeing the Weaver. The Weaver was seeing him back.

Griz dropped the globe as if it were white-hot, stumbling back with a choked gasp. It landed safely on the mossy pillow, but the psychic connection had been made. He had poked the beast, and the beast had stared back. "It knows," he whispered, his voice trembling. "It knows I can see it. It's… learning." Fizzwick and Krunk exchanged a dark, knowing look. This was what they had feared. "The shard," Griz stammered, pointing a shaky finger at the globe. "It's a piece of the knot. A piece of *him*. When I touch it, I can see where he is. What he's doing. But he can feel me looking."

Pip, roused by his cry, was suddenly beside him, her sleepy confusion replaced by sharp-eyed focus. "A sympathetic link," she breathed, staring at the globe with renewed intensity. "Like two perfectly tuned crystals. You're not just a receiver anymore, Griz. You're a transmitter. It's a two-way street." She looked at the faces of the council members, then back at Griz, and her expression was one of grim, terrible purpose. "This changes everything. We can't wait for him to come back to us. We know where he is. We know he's Topside. We have a weapon." She wasn't looking at a prybar or a spear. She was looking at Griz.The silence in the small cavern was suddenly deafening, broken only by the faint, sputtering crackle of the ruined Resonance Breaker. Pip’s words hung in the air, heavy and sharp as a guillotine’s blade. *We have a weapon.* The three other goblins in the room did not look at the prybar leaning against the wall or the spears held by Krunk’s guards outside. They looked at Griz. In their eyes, he saw a terrible, dawning calculus. He was no longer a person to be healed or comforted; he was a resource to be deployed, a tool to be wielded. The feeling was colder and more violating than any shadow tendril.

"No," Griz said, the word a ragged whisper. He took a stumbling step back, away from Pip, away from the council, away from the suffocating weight of their collective gaze. "No. You don't know what you're asking. It's not a tool. It's a leash. When I touch it, he sees me. He *feels* me. You want me to just… light myself up like a beacon so he can find me? So he can finish the job?" His voice rose, cracking with a desperation that bordered on hysteria. "I am not your weapon."

Krunk, his face a grim mask of conflict, took a half-step forward, his protective instincts warring with his duty. "The Tinker is right about the danger, but wrong about the strategy," the old warrior grunted, his gaze shifting from Griz to Pip. "We do not send a scout to do a soldier's job. The Wound-Bearer's gift is for sight. We will use it to fortify, to prepare. When the Weaver comes for us again, we will be ready. We will not chase it into the Topside world. That is madness." He spoke of Griz in the third person, as if discussing a strategic asset, and the casual dehumanization sent a fresh wave of ice through Griz's veins.

"And what happens while we wait, Krunk?" Pip shot back, her hands balling into tight fists. Her loyalty to Griz was a visible, painful thing, but her logic was a cold, sharp blade. "Do we hunker down and wait for another part of the Warren to start rotting? Do we use Griz as a glorified alarm bell, making him suffer through every little move the Weaver makes, until it finally gathers enough strength to come down here and tear us apart? Defense is a slow death. Our only chance is to strike first, while it's still wounded, while it's still angry and off-balance."

Fizzwick held up a placating hand, his eyes filled with a politician's weary sorrow. "Children, please. There is no easy path here. To send a party Topside is a risk of catastrophic proportions. But to wait is to surrender the initiative. Both roads may lead to our doom." He looked at Griz, his expression softening with a genuine pity that was almost worse than their strategic debate. "Griz, what do you say? You are the one who must bear the wound. What does your heart tell you?"

They were giving him a choice, but it was the illusion of one, a choice between being a willing sacrifice or a cowardly one. He felt trapped, a specimen pinned to a board. The silent cavern, once a sanctuary, now felt like an interrogation room. Rage, cold and clean, burned away his fear. If he was a weapon, then he would show them what it meant to be fired. He would show them the cost. With a deliberate, almost defiant motion, he limped back to the mossy recess, his jaw set. "You want to know what I see?" he rasped, his voice dropping to a low, dangerous growl. "You want to use my eyes? Fine." He ignored Pip's sudden intake of breath, Krunk's cautionary grunt. He snatched the snow globe, his fingers closing around the cold glass with a grim sense of purpose. This time, he wouldn't just touch the shard. He would command it. He would force the connection, drive it deep, and rip an answer from the void. "Let's take a look." He pressed his thumb hard against the glass, directly over the black fleck, and plunged himself into the abyss.

The connection was instant, violent, and sickeningly clear. The rainy street, the broken tangle-hound, it was all there, but he pushed past it, forcing his consciousness beyond the immediate image. He was not a passive viewer this time; he was an intruder, a burglar in the Weaver's own mind. He felt its cold, analytical anger, its surprise, but he ignored it, pushing deeper, searching for a location, a base, a next move. He followed a thread of its intention, a glimmer of forward-thinking purpose, and the world shifted around him. He found himself not in a street, but in a vast, vaulted space filled with profound silence and the ghosts of a million hurried goodbyes. Great, dusty beams of moonlight cut through a cavernous hall lined with dark, silent train platforms. Union Station. A place of forgotten journeys, a cathedral of transit now mostly hollowed out, its grand purpose reduced to a few meager tracks while its great hall slept. It was the perfect lair: a place overflowing with the faded residue of memory, a buffet for a creature like the Weaver.

He saw the Weaver standing on the marble floor of the great hall, its form less substantial than before, more like a column of solidified shadow. It wasn't building another tangle-hound. It was doing something far more insidious. It held a hand over a discarded train ticket, and Griz felt the faint, lingering echo of a young soldier's tearful farewell to his sweetheart from a war seventy years past get siphoned away, consumed. The Weaver then moved to a faded advertisement on the wall, draining the cheerful, manufactured memory of a family vacation. It was not just feeding. It was gathering specific ingredients, weaving them together. He could feel the pattern it was creating: a tapestry of sorrow, of loneliness, of departures with no return. It was building a new kind of weapon, a knot made not of trash, but of pure despair. As Griz watched, the Weaver paused, its head tilting. The cold, analytical anger he'd felt before was now focused, sharp, and directed entirely at him. It had felt his intrusion, his deliberate search. A psychic wall slammed down, booting him from the vision with the force of a physical blow.

Griz gasped, his eyes flying open, and he collapsed against the wall of the cavern, the snow globe slipping from his nerveless fingers. It rolled to a stop at Pip's feet. "Union Station," he choked out, his body trembling uncontrollably. "The big hall. It's not just feeding. It's… weaving. Something made of sadness. A sorrow-knot." He looked up at the stunned faces of the council, his eyes wild with the lingering horror of the vision. "It knows we're here. It knows we can see it. And it knows we're coming."

The debate was over. The horrified silence in the cavern was a testament to that. Griz’s self-destructive gamble had paid off, delivering a piece of intelligence so specific, so terrifying, that it left no room for argument. They had a target. Krunk was the first to move, his face set like granite. He turned to Fizzwick. "The Topside world is not our territory, but we cannot allow that… thing… to be forged. The risk of inaction is now greater than the risk of action. A small strike team. Fast and quiet. We go in, we find it, and we let the Tinker's science and the Wound-Bearer's pain finish the job." Fizzwick, his face pale, gave a slow, solemn nod. The decision was made. Pip was already on her knees, her hands hovering over the broken remains of her Resonance Breaker, her mind furiously redesigning, trying to figure out how to build a portable version, something that could be carried into battle.

Griz leaned his head back against the cold stone, the trembling finally beginning to subside. He had forced their hand. He had won the argument by losing himself. He was no longer just the Warren's oracle; he was their unwilling spearhead. As Pip began to mutter about capacitor arrays and harmonic focusing, and Krunk started barking orders for his two best scouts to be summoned, Griz looked at the snow globe. He saw his own small, green, terrified face reflected in the glass. It wasn't the face of a hero or a warrior. It was the face of a cornered animal that had just chewed off its own leg to get out of one trap, only to find itself in the center of a hunter’s sights.The council, if it could be called that, dissolved not with a formal adjournment but with a sudden, kinetic burst of purpose. Krunk, his face a thundercloud of grim determination, turned without another word to Griz and strode from the cavern, his one good arm swinging as if to counterbalance the weight of the coming battle. His voice, muffled but commanding, could be heard moments later in the corridor, barking the names of his two best scouts: "Splint! Thwack! To me, now!" Elder Fizzwick lingered only a moment longer, his old eyes resting on Griz with an expression of profound, weary empathy. He gave a slow, somber nod that was both an apology and a benediction, then shuffled out, leaving a wake of heavy silence.

Only Pip remained, her focus already turned inward. The frantic energy that had propelled her through the battle in the Marrow-Deeps was gone, replaced by a frighteningly calm, cold intensity. She stared at the cracked crystal and scorched wires of her dead machine, not with despair, but with the dispassionate eye of an engineer performing an autopsy, her mind already cannibalizing the design for its next, more lethal iteration. The cavern, Griz’s sanctuary and prison, had become the war room, and he was the map on the table. He felt invisible, an object whose function had been decided, now waiting to be picked up and used. He slid down the wall to the floor, wrapping his arms around his knees, trying to make himself small, to retreat to a place the Wound-Bearer, the spearhead, the weapon, could not be found. But there was nowhere left to hide. The quiet life of a gleaner was a foreign country whose borders were now permanently closed to him.

Pip’s workshop was a controlled cataclysm. It was a larger cavern carved out behind the main Tinker's district, and it was a testament to a life spent wrestling order from chaos. Racks of meticulously sorted screws, bolts, and capacitors lined one wall, while another was a leaning tower of salvaged circuit boards, scavenged power supplies, and gutted appliances. The air hummed with the latent energy of a dozen different projects and smelled of solder, ozone, and Pip’s ubiquitous grease. She had moved Griz here, installing his rush-mat bed in a corner where he wouldn’t be underfoot, an arrangement that felt less like convalescence and more like having a critical component on standby. For two full cycles of the Warren’s dimming and brightening lights, he watched her work. She moved with a feverish, sleep-deprived grace, her small frame a whirlwind of activity. She didn't just build; she composed, pulling a transistor from one pile, a copper coil from another, her hands a blur as she soldered and crimped, her brow furrowed in a state of fierce, creative communion with the junk of the Topside world.

During this time, Krunk's chosen scouts made their appearance. They were a study in contrasts. The first was Splint, a wiry, ancient goblin whose skin was so wrinkled it seemed to be a size too big for his bones. He moved with a liquid silence that was deeply unsettling, his eyes, hooded and patient, taking in everything and revealing nothing. He never spoke, communicating with Krunk through a series of subtle, almost imperceptible hand gestures. He carried no obvious weapons, only a collection of thin, wicked-looking knives and garrotes tucked into his patched leather jerkin. The other was Thwack, a female goblin who was Splint's opposite in every way. She was young, broad-shouldered, and radiated an aggressive, cheerful confidence. She carried a massive, two-handed war hammer cobbled together from a truck's axle and a lump of cast iron, a weapon she handled with frightening ease. She greeted Griz with a wide, toothy grin and a friendly punch to the shoulder that nearly sent him sprawling. "Heard you made a mess of things in the Tall Folk's word-house," she said, her voice a booming rasp. "Good. It's about time someone did." Splint merely watched Griz from the shadows, his ancient eyes lingering on the snow globe for a long moment before he turned away, his assessment complete and unspoken. They were the Warren's finest: its deadliest shadow and its strongest arm. And Griz was their fragile, unwilling guide.

On the evening of the second day, Pip declared her work complete. She stood back from her workbench, wiping a smear of flux from her forehead with the back of her hand, and unveiled her creation. It was not a machine; it was a rig, a harness of leather straps and scavenged metal plates designed to be worn. At its heart, where a goblin’s breastbone would be, sat a device similar to her first Resonance Breaker, but smaller, more compact, its copper coils wound with painstaking precision around a new, flawless quartz crystal. Two thick, insulated cables snaked from the main device. One led to a heavy, humming battery pack designed to be worn on the back. The other cable, thinner and more sinister, ended in a metal gauntlet, its palm fitted with a circular plate designed to hold a sphere. Pip’s eyes met Griz’s across the cluttered workshop, and the frantic energy in them was replaced by a grim apology. “I’m sorry, Griz,” she said, her voice barely a whisper. “There’s no other way to get a clean enough signal. The globe is the antenna. You’re the amplifier. You have to wear it. You have to hold the connection.” She had weaponized his curse, made it portable. She had built him a suit of armor whose sole purpose was to focus his own agony.

The departure was a quiet, solemn affair. There were no cheering crowds, no grand pronouncements. The four of them—Griz, Pip, Splint, and Thwack—gathered in a small, unused staging area near the northern maintenance shaft. Elder Fizzwick was there, his face carved with worry. He pressed a small, smooth river stone into Griz’s hand. “A stone from the deeps,” he said softly. “So you do not forget the feel of home.” Gorn the farmer appeared, his hands full of greasy parcels of roasted fungus and dried meat, enough for a week. He said nothing, but the gratitude in his eyes was a heavy weight. Krunk, his arm still in its sling, gave Thwack a blunt admonition to keep her hammer swings clear of the others, and shared a long, silent exchange of hand signals with Splint. His final gaze fell on Griz, who was struggling as Pip fitted the heavy, cold harness over his thin frame. “Bring them home, Wound-Bearer,” the old captain grunted, the words an order, not a request.

With the harness fitted and the dead weight of the battery pack settling on his shoulders, Griz felt a profound and terrible finality. He was no longer a goblin; he was a machine of war, draped in leather and wire. Pip gently placed the snow globe into the cradle on the gauntlet’s palm. The glass was cold against his skin. He looked at his hand, at the gauntlet, at the perfect, tiny world now permanently affixed to him. The quiet gleaner who collected plastic dinosaurs and loved a useless, beautiful thing was well and truly dead. He had been replaced by this creature, this living weapon, marching off to a battle he never wanted, to protect a world he was no longer sure he belonged to. He gave a single, sharp nod to Pip, unable to meet her eyes. She squeezed his shoulder, her touch a fleeting spark of the friendship that now seemed a lifetime away. Without another word, he turned and led the way to the iron ladder, the clank of Thwack’s hammer and the utter silence of Splint following him into the darkness. He ascended, pushing open the heavy manhole cover, and emerged once more into the chaotic, indifferent night of the Topside city. The humid summer air, thick with the smells of asphalt and exhaust, felt like the breath of a vast and hungry beast, and this time, he was walking willingly into its maw.The city night swallowed them whole. The alley, a familiar liminal space between the worlds, felt different this time. Before, it had been Griz’s terrified entry onto a hostile stage; now, it was a deployment zone. Under the jaundiced glare of a single sodium lamp, the four of them were a strange and monstrous tableau. Griz stood stiffly, a prisoner in the leather-and-wire cage of Pip's invention, the weight of the battery pack a constant, oppressive reminder of his new function. Pip, ignoring the city's cacophony, made a final check on a series of glowing dials on her vambrace, her face a mask of intense concentration. Thwack hefted her massive hammer onto her shoulder, the movement fluid and shockingly quiet, a predatory grin stretching her lips as her eyes scanned the rooftops. And Splint… Splint was simply gone, having dissolved into a deeper patch of shadow the moment his feet touched the pavement, his presence now just a feeling at the edge of their senses, a subtle pressure indicating the safest path forward.

They did not take the streets. To do so would have been to play by the Tall Folk's rules, on their brightly-lit grid. Instead, Splint led them on a gleaner's pilgrimage, a silent, flowing journey through the city's forgotten veins. A flicker of a hand from a darkened doorway was the signal to cross a service lane. A barely audible scrape of a boot on brick directed them up a rusted fire escape and onto the flat, tar-papered roof of a low warehouse. They moved like ghosts across a landscape of humming air-conditioning units and shadowy water towers, the city spread out beneath them as a vast, glittering carpet of indifferent lights. Thwack, for all her bulk, moved with a surprising agility, her heavy tread muffled by a practiced, rolling gait. At one point, their path was blocked by a wrought iron fence topped with cruel-looking spikes. While Griz and Pip watched, Thwack simply wrapped her large hands around two of the bars, braced her feet, and, with a silent, controlled flex of her powerful back, bent them just wide enough for the party to squeeze through, before bending them back into place with a quiet, final groan of metal.

Griz felt detached from it all, a passenger in his own body. The rig was a constant, chafing presence, and the globe on his gauntlet felt like a cold, parasitic growth. He clutched the smooth river stone from Fizzwick in his pocket, its familiar, earthy texture a tiny, desperate anchor against the overwhelming sensory input of the city. He could feel the city’s ambient sadness, a low-level hum of a million tiny heartbreaks, lonely thoughts, and forgotten dreams. It was a background radiation he had never noticed before, but now, amplified by his curse, it was a constant, wearying drone. Pip stayed close to his side, her worried eyes frequently flicking from her instruments to his face, a silent, constant query: *Are you okay?* He had no answer for her. He was a wire, humming with a current he could not control, waiting for the surge that he knew was coming.

It came when they crested the roof of an old hotel, and Union Station rose before them. It was a behemoth of brick and darkened stone, its grand, arched windows like the vacant eyes of a slain leviathan. It crouched in the heart of the city, a monument to a grander, more connected past, now largely dormant and dreaming of steam and steel. The moment it came into view, a wave of palpable misery washed over Griz, so thick and cloying it made him gag. The drone of ambient sadness sharpened into a distinct, chord of pure despair. "It's here," he rasped, his voice tight. "So heavy." The snow globe, which had been cold and inert, now glowed with a faint, violet light, the tiny obsidian shard at its heart pulsing in a slow, funereal rhythm. The sorrow-knot was awake, and it felt their approach.

Getting in was a problem for goblins, which meant it was not a problem at all. The grand front entrance, with its sweeping stone steps and heavy bronze doors, was out of the question. They circled the massive building, a small, monstrous reconnaissance team in the city’s deepest shadows. Thwack pointed with her hammer at a boarded-up window twenty feet up. "I can make a door." Pip's eyes traced a thick electrical conduit running into the basement. "Or I can short the locks on a service hatch." But it was Splint who found the way. He reappeared from the gloom near the foundation, tapping silently on a large, cast-iron grate nearly hidden by overgrown ivy. It wasn't a sewer grate. Its design was older, more ornate. A coal chute, forgotten for a century, leading down into the station's ancient boiler rooms. Thwack pried it open with the claw of her hammer, the screech of rusted iron muffled by a thick rag Splint had placed over the join. A blast of cold, stale air, thick with the scents of coal dust and something else—the sickly-sweet tang of ozone and burnt sugar—wafted up from the blackness. This was the door.

The descent was a slide into the belly of a dead thing. They dropped one by one into the chute, a dusty, iron-walled tube that plunged them deep into the station's foundations. The darkness here was absolute, a heavy, breathless black that swallowed the faint city glow from above. Griz landed with a grunt on a pile of soft, powdery coal dust, the impact jarring the rig on his back. The air was thick, suffocating, each breath tasting of rust and a deep, foundational loneliness. The change in the team was immediate. Thwack's easy confidence settled into a grim, coiled readiness, her hammer held low. Pip produced a small, hand-cranked lantern that cast a weak, flickering circle of green light, her technical focus now a sharp, defensive barrier. Splint was already ahead, a deeper shadow in the oppressive dark, scouting the way forward.

They were in the station's subterranean guts, a maze of crumbling brick corridors and massive, sweating pipes. The Weaver's corruption was here, but it was subtle, insidious. There were no thick, pulsing knots of wire like in the library. Instead, thin, black, hair-like filaments ran alongside the old electrical conduits and plumbing, like a dark mockery of the building's own nervous system. The sorrow-knot's influence was not a loud invasion; it was a deep and pervasive infection. It soaked the very stones, a psychic dampness that clung to them, heavy with the accumulated despair of a million goodbyes. The globe on Griz's gauntlet pulsed with a steady, relentless beat, a cold, purple metronome counting down to a confrontation he wasn't sure he could survive. He was a resonator now, and the song this place was singing was a dirge. He felt his own fears, his own regrets, his own shame, rising to meet it, threatening to drown him in a sorrow that was both his and not his own. The real battle, he realized, had already begun, and it was taking place inside his own skull.The oppressive silence of the station’s underbelly was a living presence, a thick, smothering blanket woven from a century of dust and neglect. Griz felt it press in on him, amplifying the drone of sorrow that was now a constant companion. The little regrets of his life, the small shames and disappointments he had always carried with a gleaner’s pragmatism, were no longer his own. They swelled, fed by the ambient despair of the place, becoming monstrous, bloated things. The memory of trading a good flint for a cracked mug felt like a catastrophic, life-altering failure. The time he’d been cheated out of a length of copper wire became a deep, searing betrayal. He clutched the smooth river stone in his pocket, its solid, thoughtless reality a desperate talisman against the rising tide of his own weaponized melancholy. In the weak, green-tinged light of Pip’s hand-cranked lantern, the air was thick with dancing dust motes, each one seeming like a tiny, lost soul trapped in an eternal, aimless waltz.

Splint materialized from the darkness ahead, a single, sharp gesture of his long-fingered hand indicating the path. They moved forward, a small island of nervous life in a dead ocean of brick and iron. The boiler room gave way to a labyrinth of narrow service corridors, the walls lined with massive, silent boilers that stood like iron gods in their tombs, their pressure gauges all reading zero. The Weaver’s insidious filaments were everywhere, not in thick, obvious knots, but as single, hair-thin strands of solidified shadow that ran along the joints in the brickwork and paralleled the ancient, cloth-wrapped wiring. Pip paused, holding her own array of sensors near one of the strands. The needles on her dials quivered chaotically, giving her no coherent data. "It’s not emitting a clear frequency," she whispered, her voice tight with frustration. "It's just… radiating noise. Psychic static. It’s designed to overwhelm, not to power anything." This wasn't engineering; it was pollution.

Their path led them past a row of rusted lockers, the changing room for porters and maintenance workers from a bygone era. As they drew level with the open, decaying doors, a wave of profound, bone-deep weariness washed over them, so potent it was almost a physical blow. It wasn't the simple tiredness of a long journey, but the soul-crushing, spiritual exhaustion of a lifetime of thankless, repetitive labor. Thwack, who had been moving with a coiled, predatory grace, stumbled, the massive head of her hammer dipping toward the floor. "Ugh," she grunted, shaking her head as if to clear it of cobwebs. "Felt like my arms were full of wet sand." She hefted the weapon again, her brow furrowed in confusion and anger. It was the first sign that this was not just Griz’s problem. The despair was an environmental hazard, leaking out and affecting them all.

For Griz, the experience was infinitely worse. The general wave of weariness resolved itself into a thousand specific, agonizing details. A phantom ache blossomed in his lower back. The ghost of callouses formed on his hands. He saw a flash, a memory that was not his own: an old, stoop-shouldered human porter, his face a mask of weary resignation, endlessly polishing a brass handrail that would only be smudged by the next day's travelers. Griz felt the man's quiet despair, the slow, grinding erosion of his spirit over forty years of thankless servitude, the knowledge that he was as much a part of the station’s infrastructure as the pipes and the bricks, and just as invisible. He gasped, stumbling into a wall, the vision leaving him breathless and shaking. Pip was at his side in an instant, her small hand on the leather of his harness. "Griz? What was it? What did you see?" He couldn't speak, could only shake his head, horrified by the intimate violation of feeling a dead man's pointless life as if it were his own.

The journey became a torturous pilgrimage through a museum of human misery. A disused lost and found office radiated a frantic, nauseating panic. A boarded-up ticket counter pulsed with the quiet, aching anxiety of a thousand final farewells. The team pushed through it, each member locked in their own private battle. Thwack took to periodically slamming the butt of her hammer against the concrete floor, the sharp, physical jolt a grounding shock against the encroaching numbness. Pip kept up a running stream of muttered technical jargon, reciting capacitor values and resistance formulas as a desperate mantra of logic against the overwhelming tide of irrational feeling. Splint remained a perfect enigma, his movements spare and efficient, his focus absolute. He navigated the psychic minefield as if it were simply another set of physical obstacles, his ancient discipline a silent, unbreakable fortress. And Griz endured. He was the focal point, the conduit for it all, the globe on his gauntlet a cold, violet eye that pulsed in the dark, drinking in the sorrow and feeding it directly into his soul.

They finally found a staircase, a narrow, rusty spiral of iron leading up from the station's gut toward its sleeping heart. With every upward step, the psychic pressure intensified. The smell of coal and decay began to recede, replaced by the ghost of floor polish and perfume, all of it curdled by the Weaver’s sickly-sweet perfume. The sorrow was no longer a dull background drone; it was a rising chord, building toward a terrible crescendo. The globe on Griz’s hand brightened, the tiny obsidian shard inside seeming to grow, its purple light casting long, distorted shadows of the goblin strike team against the curved wall of the stairwell. Griz felt a tightness in his chest, the weight of the station's collective grief trying to crush the air from his lungs. He was climbing toward the source, and he felt like a man walking willingly toward his own execution.

The staircase ended at a heavy iron fire door. Splint, silent as ever, pressed his head against the cold metal, listening for a full minute before giving a single, sharp nod. He pushed it open with a groan of protesting hinges, revealing not the Grand Hall itself, but a wide, curved mezzanine that overlooked it from on high. They stepped out onto the balcony, and the sheer scale of the despair laid out before them stole their breath. The great hall below was a cavern of moonlight and shadow, breathtaking in its lonely grandeur. In the very center of the vast, polished marble floor, directly beneath the soaring central arch, was the sorrow-knot. It was not a physical thing of wires and junk, but a shimmering, roiling distortion in the air, a vortex of pure, concentrated misery that twisted and writhed like a living wound. Faint, spectral figures flickered within it: a soldier embracing a weeping woman, a lost child crying for its mother, an old man staring at a train schedule with hollow eyes—a hundred stolen moments of human sadness, all woven together into a tapestry of pain. And orbiting this vortex, like silent, enthralled planets, were a half-dozen human figures. Janitors, security guards, the lost and the lonely who had sought shelter in the station's forgotten corners. They stood perfectly still, their faces slack, their eyes fixed on the knot as tears streamed unceasingly down their cheeks, their own quiet grief being actively siphoned off to feed the growing horror. The scene was utterly silent, hypnotic, and abominable. A scream built in Griz’s throat as the globe on his hand flared, its violet light bathing their four horrified faces in the darkness.The scream that had been building in Griz’s throat was strangled by a sudden, firm pressure on his shoulder. It was Splint’s hand, a grip as dry and light as bundled twigs, yet carrying the immovable weight of absolute command. The silent goblin did not look at Griz, his hooded gaze fixed on the horrific spectacle below, but the message was clear: *Silence. Control. Observe.* The raw, vocal horror died in Griz’s chest, curdling into a knot of cold dread that was almost as painful. He forced his breath into a semblance of rhythm, the air shuddering in and out of his lungs. Beside him, Thwack had gone utterly still, the cheerful aggression wiped from her face, replaced by a stony, murderous fury. Her knuckles were white where she gripped her hammer, the weapon held in a posture of frustrated readiness. This was a foe she could not smash, an enemy that could not be bludgeoned, and the impotence of her strength was a visible torment to her. Pip, on his other side, let out a small, choked gasp, her eyes wide with a mixture of scientific horror and deep, personal fear. She fumbled with the dials on her vambrace, but it was a reflexive, useless gesture. The needles on her readouts were spinning wildly, lost in a sea of incoherent noise, overwhelmed by the sheer, unquantifiable magnitude of the sorrow radiating from the vortex below. The scene was a masterwork of passive violence, a silent, beautiful, and utterly profane ritual that defied every law of nature and decency the goblins knew.

Splint’s hand released Griz’s shoulder and gave a single, sharp gesture, beckoning them back from the marble balustrade into the deeper shadows of the mezzanine. The four of them huddled together, a pocket of desperate conspiracy in the vast, echoing silence. Pip, recovering her composure with a visible effort, shook her head, her voice a strained whisper. “It’s not like the knot in the deeps. That was a single, coherent frequency, a parasite with a clear signature. This… this is a chorus. A thousand different griefs all singing at once. There’s no single keynote, no foundational hum for me to lock onto.” She looked at Griz, her expression fraught with a terrible apology. “My device can generate the counter-tone, but it’s like trying to shatter a specific pane of glass in a hailstorm. I need a target. You’ll have to go in there,” she pointed a trembling finger toward Griz’s mind, “and find the first thread. The original sorrow the Weaver used as the seed for this… this abomination. You have to isolate it, hold it, and become the tuning fork.” The task she outlined was monstrous. He didn’t just have to endure the storm of grief; he had to navigate it, analyze it, and pluck a single raindrop from the torrent, all while it was trying to drown him.

Thwack let out a low, guttural growl. “While you two are playing your mind-music, what about them?” She jerked her chin toward the oblivious, weeping humans below. “We can’t just leave them hooked up to that… that soul-drain.” Splint, who had been silently observing the layout of the hall, answered with a fluid series of gestures, his hands sketching a plan in the darkness. He pointed down to a shadowy service staircase on the far side of the hall, then to a massive, circular information desk of dark marble that sat near the center of the room, providing a meager island of cover. His meaning was clear, a sequence of silent commands. He would go first, his form already seeming to melt into the shadows. He would ensure the path was clear of any physical traps or watchers. Thwack would follow, her job not to attack, but to be the wall, to guard their flank and create a defensive perimeter around the desk. Griz and Pip would be the payload, moving under cover to that central point. From there, they would deploy their strange, terrible weapon. The enthralled humans were a complication he acknowledged with a flick of his wrist, a problem to be solved only after the primary threat—the knot—was neutralized. There was no room for sentiment in his cold, silent calculus.

The descent into the Grand Hall was like stepping off a cliff into a sea of cold molasses. The air on the main floor was thick and heavy, each breath a struggle. The sorrow was no longer a distant chord but a pervasive, physical presence that clung to their skin and settled in their bones. As they moved in a low crouch from the base of the staircase, darting between the shadows of immense marble columns, they drew closer to the enthralled humans. Their weeping was utterly silent, a steady, unceasing flow of tears that seemed to evaporate into a shimmering haze before they could touch the floor, drawn inexorably toward the swirling vortex. Their faces were slack and empty, their eyes fixed on the knot with the vacant, hypnotic stare of the deeply drugged. They were shells, their individual griefs being harvested like fields of grain. Griz had to force himself to look away, the sight of their quiet, helpless violation fueling a cold, hard rage that was a welcome antidote to the encroaching despair.

They reached the dubious safety of the circular information desk, its dark, polished marble cool and solid against their backs. The structure provided a low wall between them and the main entrance, but it left them terrifyingly exposed to the knot, which roiled and shimmered less than thirty feet away. The spectral figures within it were clearer now, their silent pantomimes of loss playing out in an endless, agonizing loop. From this proximity, Griz could feel the distinct flavors of their pain: the sharp, metallic tang of a soldier's fear, the suffocating, cloying sweetness of a lover's abandonment, the hollow, dusty emptiness of a parent's loss. Pip wasted no time, her hands moving with practiced efficiency as she began her final preparations. She checked the charge on the battery pack, then took the heavy cable from its housing and approached Griz. "Ready?" she whispered, her voice too small in the cavernous space. Griz looked at the weeping circle of humans, then at the pulsating vortex of despair. He gave a single, jerky nod. The click of the heavy connector locking into the port on his gauntlet was unnervingly loud, a sound of final, irreversible commitment.

Just as Pip gave Griz the final nod to begin, a voice, smooth as polished marble and cold as a tomb, echoed not in the hall, but directly inside Griz's skull. *I was wondering when you would arrive, Grizelda. The main entrance is for paying customers, but I suppose a creature of the gutter prefers a more clandestine approach. Did you enjoy the tour of my little gallery of sorrows? I find it so much more evocative than your collection of plastic lizards.* The voice was thick with a bored, condescending amusement. From the deepest shadows beneath the Grand Arch, a figure detached itself from the darkness. The Weaver stepped into the pale moonlight, its elongated form seeming to drink the light, its bruised skin and flickering, luminous veins a stark contrast to the classical beauty of the station. It wasn't attacking. It wasn't even moving quickly. It simply drifted forward, its feet not quite touching the floor, a cruel, knowing smile playing on its thin lips. It had been waiting for them. The trap was not the sorrow-knot itself. The knot was the bait, and they had swum directly into the predator’s waiting jaws.The Weaver's voice was a disease in the quiet of Griz's mind, a perfectly articulated poison that bypassed the ears and went straight for the soul. The condescending amusement in its tone was a deliberate cruelty, designed to strip away their desperate courage and leave them naked with their own futility. Griz flinched, not from a physical blow, but from the intimate violation of having his deepest-held name, his most private shame, spoken with such casual contempt by the monster that had ruined his world. The rig on his back, his so-called armor, suddenly felt like a straitjacket, binding him to a fate he was powerless to confront.

From the corner of his eye, he saw Thwack’s reaction. The goblin warrior lowered her center of gravity, her knuckles white on the haft of her hammer. The confusion and awe were gone, replaced by a simple, lethal rage. She didn't understand the psychic taunts or the nature of the sorrow-knot, but she understood a target. Her predator's grin was back, but this time it held no humor, only the promise of brutal, physical negation. Pip, however, looked utterly terrified. Her plan, her beautiful, intricate machine of logic and science, had not accounted for this. The Weaver was not a malfunctioning engine to be tuned or disrupted; it was the malevolent mechanic, and they were the broken parts it had come to discard. Her hand darted to the main activation switch on Griz’s harness, a desperate, reflexive gesture of a cornered scientist reaching for her last, most dangerous experiment.

But before anyone could act on their fear or their fury, a flicker of movement broke the stalemate. Splint, who had been a statue of shadow near the base of a pillar, moved. It was not a charge or a leap, but a single, fluid, impossible motion. One moment he was there, the next a thin, dark blade, a sliver of sharpened slate honed from the deepest rock of the Warren, was slicing through the air, aimed not at the Weaver's body, but at the point where its neck met its shoulder. It was a perfect throw, silent and impossibly fast, calculated to sever a muscle, to cripple rather than kill. The blade flew true, a whisper of goblin defiance against a cosmic horror. It never arrived. A foot from the Weaver's bruised skin, the knife simply ceased to exist. It didn't shatter or bounce off an invisible shield. It just… stopped. Its velocity, its sharp edges, its very physical substance, unraveled into a puff of gray dust and a faint, lingering smell of ozone, as if its own story had been abruptly and completely erased.

The Weaver did not even glance at the puff of dust that had been the Warren's deadliest projectile. Its shadowy eyes remained fixed on Griz, the smile on its thin lips widening. *A lovely, primitive effort,* the voice echoed in Griz’s head, dripping with patronizing praise. *Such intent. Such purpose. All that history, all that training, unwritten in an instant. Futility can be so very beautiful, don't you think?* That dismissive act of power was more terrifying than any roar or display of force. It broke something in Thwack. With a guttural bellow that shattered the hall's oppressive silence, she charged. She was a blur of green skin and furious muscle, her massive hammer held low, the floor groaning under her pounding feet. She wasn’t aiming a clumsy swing; she was driving the full, focused mass of her body and her weapon into the Weaver's center, a battering ram of pure physical conviction.

The Weaver watched her approach with the detached curiosity of a scientist observing a particularly energetic insect. It raised one long, languid hand. The polished marble floor directly in Thwack’s path rippled as if it were water. The stone did not crack or break; it simply lost its solidity. Thwack’s next step, meant to drive her forward, plunged her ankle-deep into the suddenly viscous marble. Her unstoppable momentum was instantly and utterly killed, her charge ending not with a cataclysmic impact, but with a clumsy, sucking squelch. She roared in frustration, trying to pull her leg free, but the stone clung to her like thick, cold tar, holding her fast. The Weaver made a small, dismissive gesture, and the floor solidified again, trapping Thwack’s leg in a prison of solid marble. She was caught, an enraged, living statue thirty feet from her enemy.

*Strength is just a story the muscles tell themselves,* the Weaver purred in Griz’s mind, its condescension reaching a fever pitch. *And all stories can be revised.* It turned its full attention, its full, terrible presence, back to Griz. *Now, where were we? Ah, yes. The grand finale. You came here to be a hero, Grizelda. To play a sad little song on your broken toy. Allow me to provide the accompaniment.* With a lazy wave of its hand, the roiling vortex of the sorrow-knot pulsed violently. The passive, weeping grief that had filled the hall intensified a hundredfold. It was no longer a background drone; it was a physical assault, a crushing psychic wave that slammed into Griz, threatening to extinguish his consciousness. The spectral figures in the knot grew sharp and clear, their silent screams now audible in his mind, a chorus of unending agony.

“Now, Griz! Do it now!” Pip’s shriek cut through the mental chaos, her voice raw with terror. “Find the thread! It’s our only chance!” He had to dive in. He had to immerse himself in that ocean of pain while the shark was circling. He looked at Thwack, trapped and roaring in fury. He thought of Splint, his deadliest weapon unmade. He looked at Pip, her face pale, her faith in her science shaken to its core but her faith in him somehow, impossibly, still there. He closed his eyes, shutting out the Weaver’s triumphant smirk and the swirling vortex. He shut out the cold marble and the weeping humans. He clutched the river stone in his pocket with one hand, and with the other, he let his mind fall into the cold, violet light of the snow globe, plunging headfirst into the heart of the storm.

The world dissolved into a cacophony of pure misery. He was not just seeing the memories; he was living them, all at once. He was the soldier, his heart tearing as the train pulled away from the platform, the face of his love shrinking in the distance, a face he would never see again. He was the mother whose child had let go of her hand for a single, distracted second, the ensuing minutes of frantic, screaming panic stretching into an eternity of self-recrimination. He was the old man, his life savings stolen, staring at a departure board for a train he could no longer afford, the last ember of hope in his life extinguished. The griefs were a tidal wave, each one pulling him under, threatening to drown him in its specific, exquisite pain. He was losing himself, his own identity atomizing in the storm of a thousand other lives. The Weaver’s voice was there, a silken whisper winding through the chaos. *Yes, feel it all. Feel their pathetic, beautiful pain. Let it wash you away. Isn’t it better than being a goblin? Isn’t it better than being Grizelda?*

He fought back. He held onto the smooth, solid feeling of the river stone. He pictured the sneer on Krunk’s face. He remembered the taste of Gorn’s roasted fungus. He focused on the memory of Pip, her face smudged with grease, sharpening his plastic dinosaur. Small, stupid, real things. My things. *My stories.* He pushed through the overwhelming grief of the soldier and the mother, searching for something else, something underneath. He needed the first thread, the seed. What was it? He cast his mind back, sifting through layers of sorrow, searching for a note that was different, a pain that was older. He found it. It was not a grand tragedy. It was small, quiet, and profoundly lonely. It was the memory of a little girl, no older than seven, in a simple dress from a century ago. She had dropped her doll, a simple, rag-and-button thing, onto the tracks from the platform's edge. Her father, his face stern and impatient, had pulled her away, telling her it was gone forever, that they would miss their train. Griz felt the girl's silent, helpless sorrow, a grief too small for the world to notice, the quiet, absolute finality of a child’s first true loss. It was a single, perfect, unadulterated drop of despair. This was it. The seed. The core around which all the other, grander sorrows had been woven.

*Found you,* Griz thought, a silent snarl of triumph against the Weaver’s influence. He wrapped his consciousness around the small, pure memory of the lost doll, holding it tight, protecting it from the larger, more chaotic griefs. He became its shape, its tone, its frequency. The maelstrom of other sorrows receded, repelled by the singular focus of his will. He was a tuning fork, vibrating with the ghost of a child’s quiet tears. He opened his mouth, his real mouth in the cold, silent hall, and spoke a single, croaking word. “Pip.”

The darkness was a blanket. A thick, woolly thing smelling of mold and regret. He pulled it up to his chin, a gesture he hadn't had the strength for in days, maybe weeks. The stone slab beneath him was unforgiving, leeching the last dregs of warmth from his bones. Each breath was a tiny, rattling victory against the inevitable, a small puff of steam in the cavern's chill. His skin, once a hardy shade of mossy green, was now the pale, veined color of a dying leaf. Funny, how things come full circle. He'd spent his life in the dirt, and now the dirt was patiently waiting to claim him back.

Memory is a thief that robs you in reverse. It doesn't take things from your present; it pilfers the substance of your past, leaving you with brittle, faded photographs where vibrant tapestries used to hang. But some memories... some are stubborn. They have claws. They cling to the very marrow, refusing to be dislodged by time or decay. This one, the big one, was like that. It wasn't just a memory; it was the spine of his life, the central pillar around which all other recollections were just crumbling plaster. He closed his eyes, the lids as heavy as manhole covers, and let the scent of ozone and burnt sugar pull him back. Not the smell of the damp earth and fungal rot that was his deathbed, but the smell of the beginning.

The beginning tasted like rust and smelled like the Circle City's particular brand of damp summer asphalt. He was younger then, sinewy and quick, his knuckles permanently calloused from a life of gleaning. Grizelda was his full name, a source of unending, private shame, but to everyone in the Warrens beneath Indianapolis, he was just Griz. He wasn't a hero. He wasn't destined for anything more than a full belly and a dry place to sleep. His world was the network of storm drains, forgotten subway tunnels, and crumbling basements that formed the goblin Undercity. His ambition stretched only as far as finding a particularly fine haul of copper wire or a discarded, half-eaten box of apple fritters from Taylor's Bakery.

That day, the one the memory always snagged on, he was crouched in a drainage culvert that emptied into the White River, the sluggish water lapping near his bare, three-toed feet. The air was thick with the drone of Topside traffic on the Washington Street bridge overhead. A symphony of groaning metal, rumbling tires, and the occasional, jarring blare of a horn. To Griz, it was just the city's breath, a constant, metallic exhalation. He was meticulously sorting his morning's findings on a grimy bit of canvas: three mismatched spoons, a child's plastic dinosaur (a stegosaurus, a good find), a length of insulated cable, and his prize—a mostly intact snow globe. Inside the glass, tiny plastic figures skated on a frozen pond in front of the Soldiers and Sailors Monument. He gave it a shake. White flecks swirled, a miniature, silent blizzard falling on a perfect, clean version of the city he lived beneath. It was beautiful and sad and utterly useless. He loved it.

"Find anything worth a moldy crust, Griz?"

He didn't startle. Pip's approach was as subtle as a dropped bag of wrenches, but he was used to it. She plopped down beside him, her own sack clanking softly. Pip was wiry, her ears more pointed than Griz's, and her face was perpetually smudged with grease. She was a Tinker, their Warren's best, able to coax life back into anything from a dead radio to a sputtering gas generator.

"The usual treasures of the Tall Folk," Griz grumbled, nudging the snow globe with a long finger. "They throw away their tiny, perfect worlds."

Pip picked up the stegosaurus, turning it over in her palm. "Another one for your collection?" Griz's small alcove in the Warren was cluttered with hundreds of the plastic beasts, a silent, multi-colored herd. He just grunted in response. Pip sighed, the sound lost in the river's gurgle. "You hear the whispers?"

"I try not to," Griz said, his focus on coiling the cable. "Whispers lead to rumors. Rumors lead to trouble. Trouble leads to getting your snoot smashed. It's the natural order of things."

"This is different." Her voice was low, serious. She wasn't tinkering with the dinosaur anymore. "Gretch from the lower levels? Gone. Just... gone. His scraping hook was still by his bunk. The Clutchers from the west passage haven't been seen in two cycles. And the fungus farmers say the deep-slime has a sour taste to it. A wrongness."

Griz finally looked at her. Her wide, yellow eyes were tight with genuine worry. Goblins didn't just disappear. They were too stubborn, too rooted. They died in cave-ins, or got washed out in a flash flood, or occasionally got into a fatal scrap over a shiny bit of tin. They didn't just vanish.

"It's the Shakes," Griz said, offering the most logical explanation. Every few years, the ground trembled from Topside construction or a minor fault line adjustment. Tunnels collapsed. People got lost. "The Warren settles. It happens."

"No," Pip insisted, shaking her head, her dark hair flopping. "This isn't the ground. It's the air. It feels... thin. Stretched. Like right before a lightning strike. And the smells. I was near the old canal lock yesterday. Smelled like a bonfire of sugar and burnt wires."

Ozone and burnt sugar. The scent prickled at the edges of Griz's memory, the real, waking one on the stone slab. A foreshadowing. He hadn't known it then, of course. Then, it was just another strange detail in a world full of them. Before he could formulate a properly cynical dismissal, he felt a sudden, sharp heat against his leg. He yelped and jumped up, slapping at his thigh. Tucked into a loop on his leather trousers was a small, carved bone. A rat's femur. It was glowing with a faint, pulsing orange light and was now uncomfortably hot.

Pip's eyes went wide. "By the First Stone... a summoning."

"It's a malfunction," Griz hissed, prying the hot bone from his trousers and juggling it in his palm. "Some stray voltage from the cable..."

"It's a Clutch-Mother's token, Griz, and you know it. It hasn't been used in fifty seasons. She wants to see you."

Griz stared at the glowing bone as the heat slowly subsided. Dread, cold and heavy, settled in his gut. The Clutch-Mother was the heart of the Warren, an ancient, unknowable being who dwelt in the deepest, oldest part of their world. She didn't summon gleaners. She didn't summon anyone, not for decades. You sought her out for a life-debt or a death-rite, and you hoped she didn't notice you. A direct, personal summons? It was unthinkable. It was the kind of thing that happened in the old stories. The scary ones.

"Why me?" he whispered, the question aimed at the bone, at Pip, at the indifferent river.

Pip just looked at him, her worry now mingled with something else. Awe. "I don't know, Griz. But when the heart of the Warren calls, you answer." She gently took the snow globe from his canvas. "I'll hold onto this for you. Keep it safe."

The journey to the Mother's Chamber was a descent into the Warren's history. Griz's home was in the upper levels, the "Scraplands," a chaotic maze of concrete and rusted pipes from the last century or so of Topside construction. He moved downward, past the fungal farms of the "Marrow-Deeps," where the air grew thick with the loamy scent of soil and rot, and goblins with dirt permanently etched into their skin tended to vast fields of glowing mushrooms. He passed the Tinkers' District, a cacophony of hammering and sizzling electricity where Pip's kin hammered and soldered, keeping the Warren's scavenged infrastructure humming.

He kept descending. The walls changed from brick and concrete to crudely carved earth and then, finally, to living rock, webbed with thick, ancient roots that pulsed with a slow, faint light of their own. This was the "Core," the oldest part of the Warren, predating the city above by millennia. The air was different here. Clean, but heavy. It smelled of deep earth, of stone and root and time itself. The few goblins he saw this deep were the Silent Ones, acolytes of the Clutch-Mother, their faces hidden in the shadows of their cowls. They didn't speak, but their eyes followed him, knowing. The summons had been broadcast, in its own subtle way, through the very earth of the Warren.

The entrance to the chamber wasn't a door, but a fissure in the rock, draped with thick, mossy roots that seemed to breathe. He pushed through them, the damp tendrils clinging to him for a moment before letting go. The space beyond was vast. Not a cavern, but a womb of earth and stone. The ceiling was a tangled canopy of the same glowing roots, casting a soft, golden light over everything. And in the center, she sat.

Mother Malach, the Clutch-Mother, wasn't so much sitting on a throne as she was part of it. A great, gnarled chair of living wood and stone rose from the floor, and she was entwined with it, roots coiling around her ancient, withered limbs. Her skin was the color and texture of tree bark, her eyes were closed, and she seemed as much a part of the geology as the walls around her. The only sign of life was the slow, rhythmic rise and fall of her chest. Griz had never seen her before, but he knew her. Every goblin in the Warren knew her in their bones. She was their anchor.

He stood there for a long time, the silence pressing in. It wasn't an empty silence. It was full, expectant. Like a held breath. Finally, he couldn't stand it. He cleared his throat, the sound ridiculously loud in the chamber.

"You... uh... you wanted to see me?" he croaked, feeling like the world's biggest fool.

One of her eyes opened. It wasn't the yellow of a goblin's eye. It was a solid, milky white, like an opal, and it seemed to see through him, past him, into the fizzing bundle of anxieties he called a soul.

*Grizelda,* a voice said. It didn't come from her mouth. It bloomed directly inside his head, ancient and dry as autumn leaves. *Gleaner. Collector of lost things.*

Griz flinched. He hated that name. "Just Griz, Mother."

*Names are the first thread in a tapestry, child. Yours was chosen with purpose.* Her other eye opened. *You feel it, don't you? The wrongness. The sour note in the city's song.*

He thought of Pip's words. The stretched air. The disappearing goblins. The smell of burnt sugar. He nodded dumbly.

*A thread has been pulled,* the voice in his head continued, calm and inexorable. *A dissonant chord is being struck, and the music of the world is beginning to unravel. It starts here, in the quiet places. In the spaces between. It starts with us.*

"What starts?" Griz asked, his voice a half-whisper.

*An ending. Or a new beginning. The choice is not yet made. The Loom of Ages shudders, and a Weaver of Ruin has come to unmake what is. He is one of us, and none of us. A shadow born of our own forgotten grief.*

This was too much. This was the stuff of legends, of stories told to scare little goblins into behaving. Weavers, Looms, Shadows. He was a goblin from Indianapolis. He knew about the Colts' offensive line and the best place to find discarded aluminum cans after a concert at the Murat. He didn't know about Looms of Ages.

"With all respect, Mother Malach," he said, finding a sliver of his old cynicism. "I think you've got the wrong goblin. I'm a scavenger. I pick up trash. Destiny is what happens when you miss the 38 bus and have to walk. You need a hero. A warrior. Not... me."

*The warrior sees only the battle,* the voice whispered. *The hero sees only the glory. I need a gleaner. One who finds value in what is discarded. One who knows the secret ways of the Topside world. One who understands the beauty in a tiny, perfect, broken world in a glass ball. The threads have chosen you, Grizelda. Your cynicism is a shield. Your knowledge of the lost is a map. Your shame is a tether to what you value.*

She knew about the snow globe. The thought sent a jolt of cold fear through him that was worse than anything else.

"What do you want me to do?" he asked, the fight draining out of him.

A long, woody finger, more like a twig than a digit, lifted from her armrest and pointed toward the fissure he'd entered through. *Go Topside. Find the source of the sour note. It begins at a place of accumulated memory. A place where the Tall Folk store their dead words and forgotten stories. A great library. There, another thread awaits you. Be warned. The Weaver of Ruin knows the pattern is being challenged. He will feel you move. He will send his knots and tangles to stop you.*

A library. He knew the one. The big one, downtown. He'd scavenged around its edges for years.

*Go now,* the voice commanded, a hint of iron within its leafy rustle. *The world doesn't know it's holding its breath. But you and I, we can feel it beginning to turn blue.*

The roots over her eyes closed. The audience was over. Griz stood frozen for a moment, his heart hammering against his ribs. A hero? A destiny? It was insane. It was impossible. But the certainty in her voice, the truth he felt resonating in the very rock beneath his feet... it was undeniable. He turned and stumbled out of the chamber, the weight of a world he never even knew existed settling squarely on his narrow, green shoulders. The memory was so clear, so sharp. The feel of the damp roots on his skin as he exited, the sudden understanding that his small, simple life of gleaning was over. Forever.

He stumbled back through the fissure, the mossy roots dragging across his face like the fingers of a corpse. The Silent Ones were still there, still watching, but their stillness now felt less like reverence and more like the poised silence of predators. Or jurors. He was a specimen now, a variable introduced into an ancient, cosmic equation, and they were waiting to see if he would solve for zero. He hurried past them, his bare feet slapping against the cold stone, a frantic rhythm against the slow, deep pulse of the Core.

The ascent was a blur of familiar landmarks made alien by his new-found dread. The roaring forges and acrid tang of ozone in the Tinker's District no longer sounded like industry, but like a frantic, desperate attempt to hold a failing world together with solder and spit. The earthy, comforting aroma of the Marrow-Deeps felt cloying, the scent of a grave already being dug. Every goblin he passed, every grimy face that glanced his way with casual indifference, was a fresh stab of guilt. He was supposed to save them? Him? Griz, who once traded a perfectly good water filter for a half-full bottle of hot sauce and a chipped ceramic frog. The Clutch-Mother was senile. She had to be. This was a hallucination brought on by bad fungus.

But the feeling persisted, a cold, hard certainty that had taken root in his gut, right next to the dread. He couldn't shake the memory of her voice in his head, or the impossible knowledge she’d had of his most secret, useless treasure. He tried to cling to his cynicism, wrapping it around himself like a threadbare coat, but it offered little warmth against the chill of purpose. He was a gleaner. He knew the difference between real metal and painted plastic, between a load-bearing beam and decorative plaster. And this, this mission, felt terrifyingly real.

He found Pip where he'd left her, by the river's edge. The Topside traffic still rumbled overhead, a sound he had always found soothing that now felt like the grinding of teeth. She had his few treasures neatly arranged on the canvas, and was using a small file to sharpen the points on the stegosaurus's tail. She looked up as he approached, her work forgotten. Her yellow eyes scanned his face, and the usual spark of mischief in them was gone, replaced by a deep, knowing sorrow.

"It was real, then," she said. Not a question.

Griz just nodded, slumping down onto the grimy concrete beside her. He couldn't find the words. What could he say? *'The ancient tree-goblin at the center of the earth says I have to go fight a magic shadow-man in a library to keep the world from unspooling.'* He’d be laughed out of the Warren. Or worse, pitied.

"You have to go away," she stated, her voice flat. "Topside."

"She said... she said I have to find something." He stared out at the brown, swirling water of the White River. "Something is making things wrong. And it starts up there."

"The burnt sugar smell," Pip whispered, more to herself than to him. She stopped fiddling with the dinosaur and carefully placed it back on the canvas. Then, she picked up the snow globe, cradling it in her two hands. "She said you were the one?"

Griz snorted, a bitter, humorless sound. "She called me by my full name. It was awful." He finally looked at her, at his only friend in this whole, crumbling Undercity. "Pip, this is… it's stupid. It's a story for hatchlings. I'm just a gleaner."

"You're the best gleaner," she corrected him, her voice fierce. "Who else knows the tunnels like you? Who else can find a working fuel injector in a five-ton pile of scrap? Who else sees the things the Tall Folk throw away and finds the... the story in them?" She pushed the snow globe into his hands. His fingers closed around the cool, smooth glass. "The Clutch-Mother isn't senile, Griz. She's the Warren. If she says the foundation is cracked, you'd better believe her. And if she says you're the one to patch it... well." She gave a weak, lopsided smile. "Don't mess it up."

He clutched the snow globe to his chest. It felt impossibly heavy. He went back to his alcove, a small hollow carved out behind a massive, defunct water main. The space was cramped, barely big enough for his bedroll, but it was his. He looked at the shelves he'd hammered into the concrete, at the silent, plastic herds of triceratops, raptors, and T-rexes, all salvaged from the river or the trash heaps of Topside. They were a testament to a life of small findings, of quiet, personal joys. A life that was now over. His gaze fell on the stegosaurus Pip had been sharpening. He picked it up and tucked it deep into his pocket. A single soldier from his silent army.

He packed his gleaning sack with the grim efficiency of a man preparing for a long, miserable job. He didn't have weapons, but he had tools. A sturdy prybar, his sharpest set of wire-cutters, a coil of thin, strong rope, his trusty flint and steel. He added a greasy wrap of dried mushrooms and a waterskin filled from the cleanest cistern. Lastly, he carefully wrapped the snow globe in a scrap of old felt and placed it in the very center of the sack, cushioning it with his bedroll. The weight of his world, in a bag on his shoulder.

He didn't say goodbye to anyone else. There was no one else to say goodbye to. He moved through the familiar passages of the Scraplands, his home, every drip of water and patch of phosphorescent moss a painful farewell. He headed for a maintenance shaft in the northern part of the Warren, one he used often. It ended in a manhole cover in an alley behind St. Elmo's, a place that always smelled of shrimp and steak and cleaning fluid. He paused at the base of the iron ladder, his hand on the first rung. He could still turn back. He could throw the summons-bone in the river, hide in the deepest tunnels, and let whatever was coming, come. Let some other fool be the hero.

But the image of Pip's worried face, of Mother Malach's ancient, all-seeing eye, of the tiny, perfect city inside his glass ball, pushed him upward. With a final, shuddering sigh that tasted of regret and rust, Griz began to climb, leaving the damp, earthy safety of the Undercity behind. He pushed against the heavy iron lid. It gave with a familiar groan, scraping open just enough for him to squeeze through. The night air of Topside hit him like a physical blow—a chaotic blast of distant sirens, frying food, car exhaust, and the thousand other smells of a world that never truly slept.
